attributes.title: Fork of When Does the Punishment End? The Effects of a Former Criminal Conviction on Employability and Meaning in Life
attributes.description: We examined the effects of a criminal status on society’s perceptions of an individual’s abilities as an employee, character, and meaning in life. This group of studies utilizes the sociological concept of labeling theory to discern the effects of labeling an individual as a criminal based on the presence of a previous criminal conviction on the labeled individual's employment outcomes, as well as societal perceptions and self-perception.

q1.value: Criminal History & MIL - Third application evaluation study

q3.value: Across the studies in this package, we are interested in how a previous criminal conviction impacts perceived and felt meaning in life.  We are also interested in investigating the magnitude of the employment discrimination that is faced by persons with a criminal history.

q4.value:
In the present study (i.e., the third study in our design to use job application evaluation as the principle method), we hypothesize that if a (fake) job applicant indicates a previous criminal conviction, they will...
  ...(A) be less likely to be hired by the participant
  ...(B) be rated as having a lower meaning in life
Using mediation analysis, we expect that coherence will be the facet of meaning which best explains why criminal job applicants are rated as having less meaningful lives than non-criminal applicants.  We are also investigating measurement order effects in the present study and we expect that the likelihood of hiring someone and the perception of meaning in that person's life will not be dependent on which question is asked first (we are arguing for the Null hypothesis here), though if order effects do emerge then it will impact the manner with which we are describing the impact of a previous criminal conviction (i.e., order effects would impact the narrative surrounding why a person with a criminal history would experience these effects).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Replicating the design used in two previous studies, participants will first see a job description and a faux application from someone seeking the job in question.  Participants will be led to believe that they are reviewing said application for the purpose of assisting a hiring committee at a US firm.  Critically, participants will be assigned to view either an application that indicates a previous criminal conviction or an identical application that does not.  After viewing the application, participants will complete various measures about the perceived character and qualification of the applicant, including a question about whether the applicant should be hired and four questions regarding the participant's perception of the applicant's meaning in life, coherence in life, purpose in life, and significance in life.

q9.value: simple randomization will be conducted at the participant level: each participant will be assigned to one of four possible conditions in a 2 (criminal vs. non-criminal) x 2 (item order: hiring decision first vs. last) design.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: approximately 1,000 participants will be recruited from Amazon's Mechanical Turk.  All persons must be 18 years or older to consent and participants will only be recruited from the United States.  Compensation will be $0.50 per participant.

The criminal status of the (fake) job applicant will be manipulated.  The measurement order will also be manipulated (i.e., either the hiring decision will appear first in the list of measures or last for each participant).

We will measure the perceived qualification of the applicant using a 10-point scale.  The decision of whether to hire the applicant will be a binary variable (yes or no).  Character evaluations will be made by rating six possible adjectives to describe the applicant on a seven-point Likert scale.  Meaning in life and the three facets of meaning will be measured using one item each, seven-point Likert scale.

A mean of the six character evaluation statements will be calculated as a general measure of perceived character.  All six statements reflect positive evaluations so larger numbers on this scale will reflect a more favorable character evaluation.

The impact of criminal status on hiring decision will be analyzed using chi-square and logistic regression.
The impact of criminal status on meaning in life will be analyzed using t-test.
The possibility of order effects will be evaluated by investigating (A) the main effect of order on hiring decision using logistic regression, (B) the interaction effect between order and experimental condition on hiring decision using logistic regression, (C) the main effect of order on meaning in life using ANOVA, and (D) the interaction between order and experimental condition on meaning in life using ANOVA.  Should the Null hypothesis be supported, we intend to supplement our analysis with the relevant Bayes factors.
Simple mediation effects will be carried out using Hayes' PROCESS macro - if order effects emerge then we will investigate their direction by comparing simple mediation models.  The impact of condition on meaning in life will also be explored in more detail by comparing the relative mediational effects of the three facets of meaning in this relationship.

attributes.title: Raw Data
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

additionalComments.value: My research question: Does the disproportionate amount of housework women complete in the household mediate the relationship between women's lower subjective well-being compared to men?

dataCollectionDates.value: Feb 2020 to the end of March

question2a.value: Independent variable is the sex of the respondent. Since men and women are treated as separate groups in the study, this data will be analyzed as between-participants.

question2b.value: Dependent variable is psychological subjective well-being. This is measured on a scale from 0 to 10, from 0 being 'very dissatisfied' to 10 being 'very satisfied', with a midpoint of 5.

question3b.value: The moderator expected in this correlation is the amount of housework women participate in. This is measured by the amount of hours reported spent on the activity over a week.

question10b.value: Self-report surveys will be sent out in the mail to the population living in Census Metropolitan Areas. Demographic and household questions are administered first, followed by questions on time use, activities, and wellness. Participants were not made aware of the analyses that would be conducted with their data, however previous analyses made by Statistic Canada's data is available online for participants to view.

question4b.value: People will be randomly selected from households in Canada. They will not be included if they refuse to fill out the survey or fail to fill in the data for variables reported in this study.

question5b.value: Data will be collected from Statistic's Canada's 2015 General Social Survey, using participants from Census Metropolitan Areas across Canada. Data will be collected from self-reported surveys sent out in the mail to a sample of the population.

question6b.value: Sample size should be 58. This was calculated according to gpower's expectation for 80% power at 55, plus accounting for 6% attrition.

question7b.value: Will be terminated at the end of Statistic Canada's goals for the General Social Survey (2015), which is likely when they reach a sufficient sample size of data.

question8b.value: People will be excluded from our data collection if they are not cohabiting with a spouse or partner. Housework has to be distributed over individuals to test whether the division of labor is an indicator of women's lower well-being. Missing responses (don't know, refusal, skip, not stated) and invalid responses to any of our variables will also lead to an exclusion post-data collection. Additionally, any potential outliers in our variables subjective well-being and housework will be checked for in a box and whisker plot. If any significant outliers exist, the data will be winsorized for those variables.

question9b.value: Due to the large amount of data Statistics Canada usually receives, it is unlikely data collection will not reach our anticipated sample size. But in the event our planned sample size is not obtained following our exclusion criteria, we will alter the study's design or look towards other sources of data.

question6c.value: To correct for multiple tests, we will use the Bonferroni correction to edit our alpha. This leads to a more conservative judgement when reporting for significance, so we can be assured our results are not due to the effects of multiple tests.

question7c.value: Listwise deletion will be used, where missing data will be dropped and removed from analyses.

question9c.value: If outliers are found to exist in our data, we will winsorize the relevant variables. Additionally, if skew is found to exist in our data, we will recode our data to a higher power or bootstrap our analyses.

question10c.value: We assume a normal distribution for our housework and well-being variables. We will test for skew to ensure this assumption is met. If our data is not normal, we will recode the data to a higher power or, if that does not work, bootstrap our analyses to ensure we can still make work of our variables. Another assumption is that our data has been randomly sampled from the population by Statistics Canada. We also assume our data will show a homogeneity of variance, that is, both males and females will have the same amount of variance in both variables of interest and variance will occur in a linear fashion. Another assumption made is that we will have no outliers in our data. We will test for this using a box and whiskers plot, and then winsorize the relevant variables if outliers are found.

question1a.value: The first hypothesis is that being a woman will be related to lower psychological well-being compared to men. The second hypothesis is that being a woman will also be related to carrying a greater housework burden. The final hypothesis is that housework will mediate the relationship between being a woman and having lower psychological well-being. Part of the theory behind these hypotheses suggests that this is due to the uneven division of labor between men and women, so women who are not living with their partner/spouse will be excluded from these hypotheses.

question2a.value: The relationship between being a woman and lower psychological well-being will be mediated by the amount of housework she does.

question3a.value: Manipulation checks will be made by checking our analyses afterwards on related variables that measure similar constructs, such as comparing self-rated mental health to psychological well-being. If they have a high correlation, we can assume similar constructs are being measured.

question5a.value: This is based on Gove's sex role theory that women have moved into a role overload, where they are often expected to go to work as well as perform the majority of the housework. According to this theory, this role overload among women compared to their spouses explains women's higher vulnerability to psychiatric symptoms of depression and anxiety. Distress from depression and anxiety symptoms is a construct that often overlaps with subjective well-being, which allows for my first hypothesis: that women have lower subjective well-being than men. Gove's sex role theory also presumes my second hypothesis: that women perform more housework than men. For my third hypotheses, Gove's sex-role theory will be tested with a regression analysis, looking at whether the relationship between women and lower subjective well-being is also mediated by the amount of housework they do. Bem's (1974) androgyny theory can also be noted here, where balancing a mixture of masculinity and femininity is considered ideal for well-being. Doing too much housework could be associated with practicing too much femininity, and leading to lower subjective well-being among women.

question1c.value: Sex will be dummy coded as male = 1 and female = -1, and subjective well-being will be on a scale from 0, very dissatisfied to 10, very satisfied, and assessed for normality.

question3c.value: Sex as an IV and subjective well-being as a DV

question1c.value: Sex, dummy coded as usual. Housework is measured as reported time spent on weekly housework in hours, and subjective well-being is still measured on a scale from 0 to 10

question3c.value: IV - sex, DV - subjective well-being, moderator/mediator - housework

question4c.value: Our previous correlations predict that both housework and sex is related to subjective well-being. Factoring both into this model should allow for housework to account for the differences in subjective-well being.

question1c.value: Sex, dummy coded as male = 1 and female = -1, and reported time spent on weekly housework in hours (from a possible 0 to 168)

question3c.value: IV - sex, DV - housework

question1c.value: To do a manipulation check and see if similar constructs will show the same results, self-rated mental health will also be factored into the model in place of subjective well-being in another analysis to see if these constructs map onto each other.

question3c.value: IV - kept the same as sex, DV - self-rated mental health

registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question5a: This is based on Gove's sex role theory that women have moved into a role overload, where they are often expected to go to work as well as perform the majority of the housework. According to this theory, this role overload among women compared to their spouses explains women's higher vulnerability to psychiatric symptoms of depression and anxiety. Distress from depression and anxiety symptoms is a construct that often overlaps with subjective well-being, which allows for my first hypothesis: that women have lower subjective well-being than men. Gove's sex role theory also presumes my second hypothesis: that women perform more housework than men. For my third hypotheses, Gove's sex-role theory will be tested with a regression analysis, looking at whether the relationship between women and lower subjective well-being is also mediated by the amount of housework they do. Bem's (1974) androgyny theory can also be noted here, where balancing a mixture of masculinity and femininity is considered ideal for well-being. Doing too much housework could be associated with practicing too much femininity, and leading to lower subjective well-being among women.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a: Independent variable is the sex of the respondent. Since men and women are treated as separate groups in the study, this data will be analyzed as between-participants.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b: Dependent variable is psychological subjective well-being. This is measured on a scale from 0 to 10, from 0 being 'very dissatisfied' to 10 being 'very satisfied', with a midpoint of 5.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b: The moderator expected in this correlation is the amount of housework women participate in. This is measured by the amount of hours reported spent on the activity over a week.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question6c: To correct for multiple tests, we will use the Bonferroni correction to edit our alpha. This leads to a more conservative judgement when reporting for significance, so we can be assured our results are not due to the effects of multiple tests.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question7c: Listwise deletion will be used, where missing data will be dropped and removed from analyses.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question9c: If outliers are found to exist in our data, we will winsorize the relevant variables. Additionally, if skew is found to exist in our data, we will recode our data to a higher power or bootstrap our analyses.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question10c: We assume a normal distribution for our housework and well-being variables. We will test for skew to ensure this assumption is met. If our data is not normal, we will recode the data to a higher power or, if that does not work, bootstrap our analyses to ensure we can still make work of our variables. Another assumption is that our data has been randomly sampled from the population by Statistics Canada. We also assume our data will show a homogeneity of variance, that is, both males and females will have the same amount of variance in both variables of interest and variance will occur in a linear fashion. Another assumption made is that we will have no outliers in our data. We will test for this using a box and whiskers plot, and then winsorize the relevant variables if outliers are found.
registration_responses.recommended-methods.procedure.question9b: Due to the large amount of data Statistics Canada usually receives, it is unlikely data collection will not reach our anticipated sample size. But in the event our planned sample size is not obtained following our exclusion criteria, we will alter the study's design or look towards other sources of data.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10: Self-report surveys will be sent out in the mail to the population living in Census Metropolitan Areas. Demographic and household questions are administered first, followed by questions on time use, activities, and wellness. Participants were not made aware of the analyses that would be conducted with their data, however previous analyses made by Statistic Canada's data is available online for participants to view.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: Sex will be dummy coded as male = 1 and female = -1, and subjective well-being will be on a scale from 0, very dissatisfied to 10, very satisfied, and assessed for normality.
Sex as an IV and subjective well-being as a DV
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-third.third.questi: Sex, dummy coded as usual. Housework is measured as reported time spent on weekly housework in hours, and subjective well-being is still measured on a scale from 0 to 10
Multiple regresssion
IV - sex, DV - subjective well-being, moderator/mediator - housework

Our previous correlations predict that both housework and sex is related to subjective well-being. Factoring both into this model should allow for housework to account for the differences in subjective-well being.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: People will be randomly selected from households in Canada. They will not be included if they refuse to fill out the survey or fail to fill in the data for variables reported in this study.

Data will be collected from Statistic's Canada's 2015 General Social Survey, using participants from Census Metropolitan Areas across Canada. Data will be collected from self-reported surveys sent out in the mail to a sample of the population.
Sample size should be 58. This was calculated according to gpower's expectation for 80% power at 55, plus accounting for 6% attrition.
Will be terminated at the end of Statistic Canada's goals for the General Social Survey (2015), which is likely when they reach a sufficient sample size of data.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques: Sex, dummy coded as male = 1 and female = -1, and reported time spent on weekly housework in hours (from a possible 0 to 168)
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-further.further.qu: To do a manipulation check and see if similar constructs will show the same results, self-rated mental health will also be factored into the model in place of subjective well-being in another analysis to see if these constructs map onto each other.
correlation
IV - kept the same as sex, DV - self-rated mental health
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q: People will be excluded from our data collection if they are not cohabiting with a spouse or partner. Housework has to be distributed over individuals to test whether the division of labor is an indicator of women's lower well-being. Missing responses (don't know, refusal, skip, not stated) and invalid responses to any of our variables will also lead to an exclusion post-data collection. Additionally, any potential outliers in our variables subjective well-being and housework will be checked for in a box and whisker plot. If any significant outliers exist, the data will be winsorized for those variables.

Doing too much housework could be associated with practicing too much femininity, and leading to lower subjective well-being among women.

registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question10c: We assume a normal distribution for our housework and well-being variables. We will test for skew to ensure this assumption is met. If our data is not normal, we will recode the data to a higher power or, if that does not work, bootstrap our analyses to ensure we can still make work of our variables. Another assumption is that our data has been randomly sampled from the population by Statistics Canada. We also assume our data will show a homogeneity of variance, that is, both males and females will have the same amount of variance in both variables of interest and variance will occur in a linear fashion. Another assumption made is that we will have no outliers in our data. We will test for this using a box and whiskers plot, and then winsorize the relevant variables if outliers are found.
registration_responses.recommended-methods.procedure.question9b: Due to the large amount of data Statistics Canada usually receives, it is unlikely data collection will not reach our anticipated sample size. But in the event our planned sample size is not obtained following our exclusion criteria, we will alter the study's design or look towards other sources of data.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10: Self-report surveys will be sent out in the mail to the population living in Census Metropolitan Areas. Demographic and household questions are administered first, followed by questions on time use, activities, and wellness. Participants were not made aware of the analyses that would be conducted with their data, however previous analyses made by Statistic Canada's data is available online for participants to view.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: Sex will be dummy coded as male = 1 and female = -1, and subjective well-being will be on a scale from 0, very dissatisfied to 10, very satisfied, and assessed for normality.
Sex as an IV and subjective well-being as a DV
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-third.third.questi: Sex, dummy coded as usual. Housework is measured as reported time spent on weekly housework in hours, and subjective well-being is still measured on a scale from 0 to 10
Multiple regresssion
IV - sex, DV - subjective well-being, moderator/mediator - housework

Our previous correlations predict that both housework and sex is related to subjective well-being. Factoring both into this model should allow for housework to account for the differences in subjective-well being.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: People will be randomly selected from households in Canada. They will not be included if they refuse to fill out the survey or fail to fill in the data for variables reported in this study.

Data will be collected from Statistic's Canada's 2015 General Social Survey, using participants from Census Metropolitan Areas across Canada. Data will be collected from self-reported surveys sent out in the mail to a sample of the population.
Sample size should be 58. This was calculated according to gpower's expectation for 80% power at 55, plus accounting for 6% attrition.
Will be terminated at the end of Statistic Canada's goals for the General Social Survey (2015), which is likely when they reach a sufficient sample size of data.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques: Sex, dummy coded as male = 1 and female = -1, and reported time spent on weekly housework in hours (from a possible 0 to 168)
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-further.further.qu: To do a manipulation check and see if similar constructs will show the same results, self-rated mental health will also be factored into the model in place of subjective well-being in another analysis to see if these constructs map onto each other.
correlation
IV - kept the same as sex, DV - self-rated mental health
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q: People will be excluded from our data collection if they are not cohabiting with a spouse or partner. Housework has to be distributed over individuals to test whether the division of labor is an indicator of women's lower well-being. Missing responses (don't know, refusal, skip, not stated) and invalid responses to any of our variables will also lead to an exclusion post-data collection. Additionally, any potential outliers in our variables subjective well-being and housework will be checked for in a box and whisker plot. If any significant outliers exist, the data will be winsorized for those variables.

attributes.title: Stimulated Data
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

additionalComments.value: My research question: Does the disproportionate amount of housework women complete in the household mediate the relationship between women's lower subjective well-being compared to men?

dataCollectionDates.value: Feb 2020 to the end of March

question2a.value: Independent variable is the sex of the respondent. Since men and women are treated as separate groups in the study, this data will be analyzed as between-participants.

question2b.value: Dependent variable is psychological subjective well-being. This is measured on a scale from 0 to 10, from 0 being 'very dissatisfied' to 10 being 'very satisfied', with a midpoint of 5.

question3b.value: The moderator expected in this correlation is the amount of housework women participate in. This is measured by the amount of hours reported spent on the activity over a week.

question10b.value: Self-report surveys will be sent out in the mail to the population living in Census Metropolitan Areas. Demographic and household questions are administered first, followed by questions on time use, activities, and wellness. Participants were not made aware of the analyses that would be conducted with their data, however previous analyses made by Statistic Canada's data is available online for participants to view.

question4b.value: People will be randomly selected from households in Canada. They will not be included if they refuse to fill out the survey or fail to fill in the data for variables reported in this study.

question5b.value: Data will be collected from Statistic's Canada's 2015 General Social Survey, using participants from Census Metropolitan Areas across Canada. Data will be collected from self-reported surveys sent out in the mail to a sample of the population.

question6b.value: Sample size should be 58. This was calculated according to gpower's expectation for 80% power at 55, plus accounting for 6% attrition.

question7b.value: Will be terminated at the end of Statistic Canada's goals for the General Social Survey (2015), which is likely when they reach a sufficient sample size of data.

question8b.value: People will be excluded from our data collection if they are not cohabiting with a spouse or partner. Housework has to be distributed over individuals to test whether the division of labor is an indicator of women's lower well-being. Missing responses (don't know, refusal, skip, not stated) and invalid responses to any of our variables will also lead to an exclusion post-data collection. Additionally, any potential outliers in our variables subjective well-being and housework will be checked for in a box and whisker plot. If any significant outliers exist, the data will be winsorized for those variables.

question9b.value: Due to the large amount of data Statistics Canada usually receives, it is unlikely data collection will not reach our anticipated sample size. But in the event our planned sample size is not obtained following our exclusion criteria, we will alter the study's design or look towards other sources of data.

question6c.value: To correct for multiple tests, we will use the Bonferroni correction to edit our alpha. This leads to a more conservative judgement when reporting for significance, so we can be assured our results are not due to the effects of multiple tests.

question7c.value: Listwise deletion will be used, where missing data will be dropped and removed from analyses.

question9c.value: If outliers are found to exist in our data, we will winsorize the relevant variables. Additionally, if skew is found to exist in our data, we will recode our data to a higher power or bootstrap our analyses.

question10c.value: We assume a normal distribution for our housework and well-being variables. We will test for skew to ensure this assumption is met. If our data is not normal, we will recode the data to a higher power or, if that does not work, bootstrap our analyses to ensure we can still make work of our variables. Another assumption is that our data has been randomly sampled from the population by Statistics Canada. We also assume our data will show a homogeneity of variance, that is, both males and females will have the same amount of variance in both variables of interest and variance will occur in a linear fashion. Another assumption made is that we will have no outliers in our data. We will test for this using a box and whiskers plot, and then winsorize the relevant variables if outliers are found.

question1a.value: The first hypothesis is that being a woman will be related to lower psychological well-being compared to men. The second hypothesis is that being a woman will also be related to carrying a greater housework burden. The final hypothesis is that housework will mediate the relationship between being a woman and having lower psychological well-being. Part of the theory behind these hypotheses suggests that this is due to the uneven division of labor between men and women, so women who are not living with their partner/spouse will be excluded from these hypotheses.

question2a.value: The relationship between being a woman and lower psychological well-being will be mediated by the amount of housework she does.

question3a.value: Manipulation checks will be made by checking our analyses afterwards on related variables that measure similar constructs, such as comparing self-rated mental health to psychological well-being. If they have a high correlation, we can assume similar constructs are being measured.

question5a.value: This is based on Gove's sex role theory that women have moved into a role overload, where they are often expected to go to work as well as perform the majority of the housework. According to this theory, this role overload among women compared to their spouses explains women's higher vulnerability to psychiatric symptoms of depression and anxiety. Distress from depression and anxiety symptoms is a construct that often overlaps with subjective well-being, which allows for my first hypothesis: that women have lower subjective well-being than men. Gove's sex role theory also presumes my second hypothesis: that women perform more housework than men. For my third hypotheses, Gove's sex-role theory will be tested with a regression analysis, looking at whether the relationship between women and lower subjective well-being is also mediated by the amount of housework they do. Bem's (1974) androgyny theory can also be noted here, where balancing a mixture of masculinity and femininity is considered ideal for well-being. Doing too much housework could be associated with practicing too much femininity, and leading to lower subjective well-being among women.

question1c.value: Sex will be dummy coded as male = 1 and female = -1, and subjective well-being will be on a scale from 0, very dissatisfied to 10, very satisfied, and assessed for normality.

question3c.value: Sex as an IV and subjective well-being as a DV

question1c.value: Sex, dummy coded as usual. Housework is measured as reported time spent on weekly housework in hours, and subjective well-being is still measured on a scale from 0 to 10

question3c.value: IV - sex, DV - subjective well-being, moderator/mediator - housework

question4c.value: Our previous correlations predict that both housework and sex is related to subjective well-being. Factoring both into this model should allow for housework to account for the differences in subjective-well being.

question1c.value: Sex, dummy coded as male = 1 and female = -1, and reported time spent on weekly housework in hours (from a possible 0 to 168)

question3c.value: IV - sex, DV - housework

question1c.value: To do a manipulation check and see if similar constructs will show the same results, self-rated mental health will also be factored into the model in place of subjective well-being in another analysis to see if these constructs map onto each other.

question3c.value: IV - kept the same as sex, DV - self-rated mental health

registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: People will be randomly selected from households in Canada. They will not be included if they refuse to fill out the survey or fail to fill in the data for variables reported in this study.

Data will be collected from Statistic's Canada's 2015 General Social Survey, using participants from Census Metropolitan Areas across Canada. Data will be collected from self-reported surveys sent out in the mail to a sample of the population.
Sample size should be 58. This was calculated according to gpower's expectation for 80% power at 55, plus accounting for 6% attrition.
Will be terminated at the end of Statistic Canada's goals for the General Social Survey (2015), which is likely when they reach a sufficient sample size of data.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques: Sex, dummy coded as male = 1 and female = -1, and reported time spent on weekly housework in hours (from a possible 0 to 168)
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-further.further.qu: To do a manipulation check and see if similar constructs will show the same results, self-rated mental health will also be factored into the model in place of subjective well-being in another analysis to see if these constructs map onto each other.
correlation
IV - kept the same as sex, DV - self-rated mental health
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q: People will be excluded from our data collection if they are not cohabiting with a spouse or partner. Housework has to be distributed over individuals to test whether the division of labor is an indicator of women's lower well-being. Missing responses (don't know, refusal, skip, not stated) and invalid responses to any of our variables will also lead to an exclusion post-data collection. Additionally, any potential outliers in our variables subjective well-being and housework will be checked for in a box and whisker plot. If any significant outliers exist, the data will be winsorized for those variables.

attributes.title: Analysis Directory
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

additionalComments.value: My research question: Does the disproportionate amount of housework women complete in the household mediate the relationship between women's lower subjective well-being compared to men?

dataCollectionDates.value: Feb 2020 to the end of March

question2a.value: Independent variable is the sex of the respondent. Since men and women are treated as separate groups in the study, this data will be analyzed as between-participants.

question2b.value: Dependent variable is psychological subjective well-being. This is measured on a scale from 0 to 10, from 0 being 'very dissatisfied' to 10 being 'very satisfied', with a midpoint of 5.

question3b.value: The moderator expected in this correlation is the amount of housework women participate in. This is measured by the amount of hours reported spent on the activity over a week.

question10b.value: Self-report surveys will be sent out in the mail to the population living in Census Metropolitan Areas. Demographic and household questions are administered first, followed by questions on time use, activities, and wellness. Participants were not made aware of the analyses that would be conducted with their data, however previous analyses made by Statistic Canada's data is available online for participants to view.

question4b.value: People will be randomly selected from households in Canada. They will not be included if they refuse to fill out the survey or fail to fill in the data for variables reported in this study.

question5b.value: Data will be collected from Statistic's Canada's 2015 General Social Survey, using participants from Census Metropolitan Areas across Canada. Data will be collected from self-reported surveys sent out in the mail to a sample of the population.

question6b.value: Sample size should be 58. This was calculated according to gpower's expectation for 80% power at 55, plus accounting for 6% attrition.

question7b.value: Will be terminated at the end of Statistic Canada's goals for the General Social Survey (2015), which is likely when they reach a sufficient sample size of data.

question8b.value: People will be excluded from our data collection if they are not cohabiting with a spouse or partner. Housework has to be distributed over individuals to test whether the division of labor is an indicator of women's lower well-being. Missing responses (don't know, refusal, skip, not stated) and invalid responses to any of our variables will also lead to an exclusion post-data collection. Additionally, any potential outliers in our variables subjective well-being and housework will be checked for in a box and whisker plot. If any significant outliers exist, the data will be winsorized for those variables.

question9b.value: Due to the large amount of data Statistics Canada usually receives, it is unlikely data collection will not reach our anticipated sample size. But in the event our planned sample size is not obtained following our exclusion criteria, we will alter the study's design or look towards other sources of data.

question6c.value: To correct for multiple tests, we will use the Bonferroni correction to edit our alpha. This leads to a more conservative judgement when reporting for significance, so we can be assured our results are not due to the effects of multiple tests.

question7c.value: Listwise deletion will be used, where missing data will be dropped and removed from analyses.

question9c.value: If outliers are found to exist in our data, we will winsorize the relevant variables. Additionally, if skew is found to exist in our data, we will recode our data to a higher power or bootstrap our analyses.

question10c.value: We assume a normal distribution for our housework and well-being variables. We will test for skew to ensure this assumption is met. If our data is not normal, we will recode the data to a higher power or, if that does not work, bootstrap our analyses to ensure we can still make work of our variables. Another assumption is that our data has been randomly sampled from the population by Statistics Canada. We also assume our data will show a homogeneity of variance, that is, both males and females will have the same amount of variance in both variables of interest and variance will occur in a linear fashion. Another assumption made is that we will have no outliers in our data. We will test for this using a box and whiskers plot, and then winsorize the relevant variables if outliers are found.

question1a.value: The first hypothesis is that being a woman will be related to lower psychological well-being compared to men. The second hypothesis is that being a woman will also be related to carrying a greater housework burden. The final hypothesis is that housework will mediate the relationship between being a woman and having lower psychological well-being. Part of the theory behind these hypotheses suggests that this is due to the uneven division of labor between men and women, so women who are not living with their partner/spouse will be excluded from these hypotheses.

question2a.value: The relationship between being a woman and lower psychological well-being will be mediated by the amount of housework she does.

question3a.value: Manipulation checks will be made by checking our analyses afterwards on related variables that measure similar constructs, such as comparing self-rated mental health to psychological well-being. If they have a high correlation, we can assume similar constructs are being measured.

question5a.value: This is based on Gove's sex role theory that women have moved into a role overload, where they are often expected to go to work as well as perform the majority of the housework. According to this theory, this role overload among women compared to their spouses explains women's higher vulnerability to psychiatric symptoms of depression and anxiety. Distress from depression and anxiety symptoms is a construct that often overlaps with subjective well-being, which allows for my first hypothesis: that women have lower subjective well-being than men. Gove's sex role theory also presumes my second hypothesis: that women perform more housework than men. For my third hypotheses, Gove's sex-role theory will be tested with a regression analysis, looking at whether the relationship between women and lower subjective well-being is also mediated by the amount of housework they do. Bem's (1974) androgyny theory can also be noted here, where balancing a mixture of masculinity and femininity is considered ideal for well-being. Doing too much housework could be associated with practicing too much femininity, and leading to lower subjective well-being among women.

question1c.value: Sex will be dummy coded as male = 1 and female = -1, and subjective well-being will be on a scale from 0, very dissatisfied to 10, very satisfied, and assessed for normality.

question3c.value: Sex as an IV and subjective well-being as a DV

question1c.value: Sex, dummy coded as usual. Housework is measured as reported time spent on weekly housework in hours, and subjective well-being is still measured on a scale from 0 to 10

question3c.value: IV - sex, DV - subjective well-being, moderator/mediator - housework

question4c.value: Our previous correlations predict that both housework and sex is related to subjective well-being. Factoring both into this model should allow for housework to account for the differences in subjective-well being.

question1c.value: Sex, dummy coded as male = 1 and female = -1, and reported time spent on weekly housework in hours (from a possible 0 to 168)

question3c.value: IV - sex, DV - housework

question1c.value: To do a manipulation check and see if similar constructs will show the same results, self-rated mental health will also be factored into the model in place of subjective well-being in another analysis to see if these constructs map onto each other.

question3c.value: IV - kept the same as sex, DV - self-rated mental health
